ygData.subject: Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: The question about crossover in NEAT is interesting.  Although it does not provide a huge boost in performance, it is still a significant advance compared to

The question about crossover in NEAT is interesting.  Although it does
not =
provide a huge boost in performance, it is still a significant
advance comp=
ared to what came before in neuroevolution, which is why
it is still a payo=
ff.  The competing conventions problem (also called
the "topology matching =
problem") was a huge issue in neuroevolution
before NEAT, and because of it=
 some researchers were questioning
whether there was any hope for crossover=
 at all in such systems.  It
could be shown in prior systems without histor=
ical marking that
crossover actually hurts the evolution of neural networks=
, making its
prospects dim.  Angeline and Pollack even introduced a neuroev=
olution
method called GNARL (before NEAT) that didn't even have crossover a=
s
an operator because of the concern.  In this context, NEAT made
crossover=
 safe for neuroevolution and removed its stigma in such
systems.  That is, =
it switched it from a liability to an advantage
that boosts performance a b=
it in NEAT.  So it's an advance in that sense.

However, while the "bit" of=
 performance gain (vs. having no crossover)
*is* likely statistically signi=
ficant, it is not huge.  The real
benefit of historical markings
is that it=
 enables speciation, which does have a dramatic effect
because of protectin=
g innovation to support complexification. 
Crossover is more like icing on =
the cake.  However, I think many
people identify NEAT with crossover becaus=
e it is such a clear
demonstration of the benefit of historical markings.  =
In that sense,
it is perhaps conceptually more significant than it is funct=
ionally. 
Still, I would recommend keeping it if you can, since it does app=
ear
to be better to have it than not, albeit not enormously.

ken

=

> intel=
ligent crossover via historical markings? I guess I just
assumed that
> had=
 been shown to provide a huge payoff. If crossover doesn't help
that much
>=
 in NEAT, how much does *intelligent* (vs. na=EFve) crossover help?
>

er completely chooses one parent or the other, but putting that

ll perform real crossover).

ng, I'll roll this into the next

 --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>> 
> >>>>> W=
ell yes this is exactly what it has to be. Note that
> > randomChoice has
>=
 >>>>> to be random every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e.
>=
 >>>>> outside the big loop) then you choose links from either parent.
> > =
But if
> >>>>> it is inside the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from =
either
> >>>>> parent. Check this out and you will have a clearer picture i=
f
> > there is
> >>>>> a bug or not.
> >>>> 
> >>>> Thanks Petar. I am conf=
ident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the parent
> >>> outside
> >>>> the loop, =
and thus grabs all links from either parent1 or parent2.
> >>> What I am
> =
>>>> trying to find out is whether this is by design, or if it is a bug.
> =
>>>>

EAT
> >>> packages,

 is that we are

> >>>> be grabbing some links from parent=
1 and some other links from
> > parent2,

. I can go check those packages, of

e to do that for a little while and was wondering
if any
> >>> of you
> >>>=
> knew off the top of your heads.

a deeper one. In this case you must
ensure
> >>>>> that individuals should =
not mate with themselves or such ones that
> >>>>> have zero compatibility =
distance. Or at least try a few hundred
> > times
> >>>>> to find a differe=
nt mate :) Hey, I say this to all users.
Don't use
> >>>>> rand(), fuck tha=
t, use the Mersenne Twister instead. I noticed
> > that in
> >>>>> enhances=
 performance!

n the more

ough. I will delve into them

lementation is different than

u download the package, the key file is:

eneticIndividual.cpp

 how that works with the yahoo

occurs in this constructor:
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>>

al::GeneticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
> >>>>>> parent1,shared=
_ptr<GeneticIndividual> parent2,bool

> >>>>>> The following line occurs outside of the loop that goes through

 > each

mChoice<=3Dparent1->getFitness());

p for each link:

> >>>>>>                     if (chooseFirstPare=
nt)

> >>>>>>                         addLink=
(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));

            else

      addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
> >>>>>>                     }

>>>>

ogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

> >>>>> P=
NEAT?
> >>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>> Hi Jeff, 
> >>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>> Well I don't know=
 about the exact implementations of
HyperNEAT you
> >>>>> are
> >>>>>>> usi=
ng (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations
> >>>>>>> disable=
d), but in principle crossover should choose genes
randomly
> >>>>>>> from =
both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the
child. In
> >>>>>>> Hyp=
erNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a
> >>>>> regular
=
> >>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other networks based
on the=

> >>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and mutate the
>=
 >>>>> CPPNs.
> >>>>>>> But in the case you get lots of individuals with eq=
ual
fitness, I
> >>>>>>> guess these individuals are clones. Perhaps the co=
de frequently
> >>>>>>> chooses the same individuals for mating? You can tr=
y to
avoid this
> >>>>> by
> >>>>>>> introducing a loop in which you try ca=
ndidates for a
"father" that
> >>>>> are
> >>>>>>> not compatible with the =
mother, that is, when their
compatibility
> >>>>>>> distance is 0.00, try a=
gain. There is another possibility,
simply
> >>>>>>> every mutation disturb=
s the CPPN and therefore the produced
> >>>>> network is
> >>>>>>> changed =
in such a magnitude that is has no chance for
survival and
> >>>>> is
> >>>=
>>>> discarded. Even though there is speciation.
> >>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>> Peter=

> >>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <j=
clune@> wrote:
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> Hello all-
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> Doe=
s crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> PNEA=
T:
> >>>>>>>> If I am reading the code correctly, during crossover, if the
=
> >>>>>>> substrates are
> >>>>>>>> the same (i.e. all links have the same =
ID), which is always the
> >>>>> case
> >>>>>>> in
> >>>>>>>> P-NEAT, *all*=
 of the link values are taken from either
parent1 or
> >>>>>>> parent2.
> >=
>>>>>>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over to take some from
parent1
>=
 >>>>>>> and some
> >>>>>>>> from parent2? Why grab all from just one?
> >>=
>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right? =
It will
> >>>>>>> always grab
> >>>>>>>> the substrate of parent1 or the su=
bstrate of parent2.  If I
track
> >>>>>>> parent and
> >>>>>>>> offspring f=
itness, 100% of the time the child has the exact
same
> >>>>>>> fitness as
=
> >>>>>>>> one of the two parents.
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> On to HyperNEAT:
=
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulti=
ng
offspring.
> >>>>>>> The odd
> >>>>>>>> thing is that the organisms that=
 are crossed only (i.e.
they are
> >>>>>>> never
> >>>>>>>> mutated) have t=
he *exact* same fitness of one of their parents
> >>>>>>> 98.88% of the
> >=
>>>>>>> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were
> >=
>>>>>> crossed over
> >>>>>>>> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't i=
t? Why would these
> >>>>> new
> >>>>>>> links
> >>>>>>>> have such a small=
 impact? It turns out that this is because
> >>>>> nearly
> >>>>>>> every
>=
 >>>>>>>> time that there is an extra link that gets placed in the child,
>=
 >>>>> the
> >>>>>>> parent
> >>>>>>>> that donated that link is also the p=
arent whose weights are
being
> >>>>>>> grabbed,
> >>>>>>>> meaning that th=
e crossover is only copying the parent
(hence the
> >>>>>>> same
> >>>>>>>>=
 fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be much more
> >>>>>>> disr=
uptive, no?
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>> As a final test, I did a set=
 of hyperneat and pneat runs
with the
> >>>>>>> default
> >>>>>>>> 'MutateO=
nlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs
> >>>>> never
> >>>>>>=
> are
> >>>>>>>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental treatmen=
ts
> >>>>>>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the
> >>>>> MutateO=
nlyProbability
> >>>>>>>> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed o=
ver.
Despite my
> >>>>>>> comments
> >>>>>>>> above, Hyperneat (with cross)=
 did beat HyperNEAT-noCross,
however
> >>>>>>> the
> >>>>>>>> difference wa=
s not tremendous (although it does seem to be
> >>>>>>> statistically
> >>>=
>>>>> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless,
> >>>>>=
 this
> >>>>>>> is not a
> >>>>>>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays =
dividends, because if
> >>>>>>> crossover does
> >>>>>>>> nothing most of t=
he time, and I increase MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>> from
> >>>>>>> .25 to=

> >>>>>>>> 1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> >=
>>>> crossed
> >>>>>>> orgs are
> >>>>>>>> also mutated).
> >>>>>>>> 
> >>>=
>>>>> Are these the intended consequences of crossover, or am I
missing
> >=
>>>>>> something?
> >>>>>>>>
